wesm commented on issue #5373: ARROW-6429: [Python] Always return pandas.Series from Array/ChunkedArray.to_pandas. Add mechanism to preserve "column names" from RecordBatch, Table as Series.name
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5373#issuecomment-531264154
 
 
   @BryanCutler this seems to be mostly working again. There are some timestamp-related failures, though
   
   ```
   ======================================================================
   FAIL: test_vectorized_udf_timestamps (pyspark.sql.tests.test_pandas_udf_scalar.ScalarPandasUDFTests)
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Traceback (most recent call last):
     File "/spark/python/pyspark/sql/tests/test_pandas_udf_scalar.py", line 682, in test_vectorized_udf_timestamps
       self.assertEquals(data[i][1], result[i][2])  # "timestamp_copy" col
   AssertionError: datetime.datetime(1969, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) != datetime.datetime(1969, 1, 1, 9, 1, 1)
   
   ======================================================================
   FAIL: test_vectorized_udf_timestamps_respect_session_timezone (pyspark.sql.tests.test_pandas_udf_scalar.ScalarPandasUDFTests)
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Traceback (most recent call last):
     File "/spark/python/pyspark/sql/tests/test_pandas_udf_scalar.py", line 768, in test_vectorized_udf_timestamps_respect_session_timezone
       self.assertEqual(result_ny, result_la_corrected)
   AssertionError: Lists differ: [Row([39 chars], 1, 6, 1, 1), internal_value=-315035390000000[235 chars]000)] != [Row([39 chars], 1, 9, 1, 1), (internal_value + 1080000000000[313 chars]000)]
   
   First differing element 0:
   Row(i[38 chars], 1, 6, 1, 1), internal_value=-31503539000000000)
   Row(i[38 chars], 1, 9, 1, 1), (internal_value + 1080000000000[17 chars]0000)
   
   Diff is 1397 characters long. Set self.maxDiff to None to see it.
   
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   ```
   
   This could be caused by https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/6f724576a98651ed32d915aa5367bd3b03bb4a86 but I'm not sure what the problem could be

BryanCutler commented on pull request #5465: ARROW-6429: [Integration] Adding patch to fix Spark compilation for Integrition tests
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5465#discussion_r326883418
 
 

 ##########
 File path: integration/spark/runtest.sh
 ##########
 @@ -28,6 +28,9 @@ popd
 export MAVEN_OPTS="-Xmx2g -XX:ReservedCodeCacheSize=512m -Dorg.slf4j.simpleLogger.defaultLogLevel=warn"
 export MAVEN_OPTS="${MAVEN_OPTS} -Dorg.slf4j.simpleLogger.log.org.apache.maven.cli.transfer.Slf4jMavenTransferListener=warn"
 
+echo "Patching Spark"
+patch -d /spark -p1 -i /arrow/integration/spark/ARROW-6429.patch
 
 Review comment:
   @kszucs I thought this would be better in the Dockerfile after checking out spark, but for some reason the patch didn't seem to apply. I was trying this and it seemed to run, but the file wasn't patched
   ```
   COPY integration/spark/spark-arrow-java-IpcOption.patch /spark/
   RUN patch -d /spark -p1 -i /tmp/spark-arrow-java-IpcOption.patch
   ```
   Any ideas?

   > Any ideas how could we speed up the spark integration test a bit?

Also, the pyspark tests run twice, once against python and python3.6, which I think are the same in this image. So we can just explicitly test one and that will save a couple minutes I think.

BryanCutler commented on issue #5465: ARROW-6429: [Integration] Adding patch to fix Spark compilation for Integrition tests
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5465#issuecomment-534352023
 
 
   @kszucs , I made a couple small adjustments but I think the reason for the timeout is that Spark can take a long time during assembly, which downloads and assembles all required dependencies. I don't think there is anyway to avoid this since we need to test pyspark, but perhaps there is someway to cache better.
   
   Since this could take a long time and we limit the output during the build to just warnings, we end up hitting the "too long without output" timeout. Is it possible to increase this by setting `no_output_timeout` to something like 30min?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description: See https://circleci.com/gh/ursa-labs/crossbow/2310. Either fix, skip job and create followup Jira to unskip, or delete job.

comments.body: [~bryanc] can you take a look, or suggest someone else?
I will take a look, but it might be a few days until I can get to it.

The failure seems to be caused from the removal of pyarrow.Column in favor of pyarrow.ChunkedArray. Spark iterates over columns of a pyarrow.Table, calls {{to_pandas()}} on each column, and assumes the result is a pd.Series. If the column is actually a pyarrow.ChunkedArray, then {{to_pandas()}} can be a numpy.array. [~wesmckinn] [~pitrou] I know in the pydoc it says the returned value can either be a pandas.Series or numpy.array, but is there anyway to ensure it is the former or is that the job of the caller?
I'd be OK with always return {{pandas.Series}} but I'm not sure what are the implications of this change
After ARROW-6557 there seems to be another issue with timestamps [https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5373#issuecomment-531264154.]  I'll look into this soon.

[~wesm] the issue with the timestamp test failures looks to be because calling {{to_pandas}} on a pyarrow ChunkedArray with a tz aware timestamp type removes the tz from the resulting dtype. The behavior before was a pyarrow Column keeps the tz but the pyarrow Array removes when converting to a numpy array.

With Arrow 0.14.1
{code:java}
In [4]: import pyarrow as pa 
   ...: a = pa.array([1], type=pa.timestamp('us', tz='America/Los_Angeles'))  
   ...: c = pa.Column.from_array('ts', a) 

In [5]: c.to_pandas()                                                                                                        
Out[5]: 
0   1969-12-31 16:00:00.000001-08:00
Name: ts, dtype: datetime64[ns, America/Los_Angeles]

In [6]: a.to_pandas()                                                                                                        
Out[6]: array(['1970-01-01T00:00:00.000001'], dtype='datetime64[us]')
{code}
With current master
{code:java}
>>> import pyarrow as pa
>>> a = pa.array([1], type=pa.timestamp('us', tz='America/Los_Angeles'))
>>> a.to_pandas()
0   1970-01-01 00:00:00.000001
dtype: datetime64[ns]
{code}
After manually adding the timezone back in the series dtype (and fixing the Java compilation), all tests pass and the spark integration run finished. I wasn't able to look into why the timezone is being removed though. Should I open up a jira for this?

edit: I made ARROW-6652 since it is not just a Spark issue
This may be fixed in master now, need to confirm
I believe I need to add a patch so Spark can compile with Arrow Java. I'm working on this now.
Tests are passing since ARROW-6686 was merged, I'll resolve this now
